awd_titl_txt: Embedding Equitable Design through Undergraduate Computing Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by investigating a new approach to teaching computer science (CS) that fosters inclusive and equitable practices. The structure of a typical undergraduate computer science degree program has changed little in decades. The curricula rarely include courses like CS ethics or usability that teach CS students how systems affect people and society. When such courses are included, they are largely disconnected from the rest of the CS degree. As a result, students entering the workforce tend to design software that is highly inequitable for large portions of the intended users of that software. This project will investigate a new approach to teaching CS that embeds equitable software design into computing courses throughout all four years of the undergraduate CS curriculum. The new approach does not require large changes to the curriculum, but instead integrates equity and inclusion into the CS work the students are already doing. Through the participation of three universities, over 20 faculty, and over 6000 students, this project will investigate the effectiveness, sustainability, and impact of the new approach.

This project is based on the foundations of equitable design methods. The expected results of this project will include new course materials to support transforming an existing CS curriculum to one that embeds equitable design, and professional development for faculty to foster success at embedding equitable software design into their courses. Research questions that will be investigated as part of this work will generate knowledge that will allow CS teachers to better understand the impacts of the changes on the ability of students to create high-quality software that is equitable, the impacts on the culture in computing classes and majors, and the feasibility of the approach across several different educational settings. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

●      Intellectual merit:

This computer science (CS) education project investigated integrating concepts from a universal design method into most undergraduate computer science classes.  Universal design methods expand the swath of potential users who can benefit from a software product. The economic benefit of teaching universal design methods to CS students is that it enables future software professionals to create software products that work better for more people.

The project’s results showed that integrating these concepts into the CS classes produced many educational benefits. For example, students’ grades in these classes improved, and so did their retention in the major.  The students also demonstrated their new skills in the software they created, which outside experts rated more highly than the software of students that had come before.  The educational benefits went even further – students’ ratings of their faculty instructors increased, their ratings of belongingness in computing fields increased, and their ratings of their own teamwork with each other increased.  Figure 1 summarizes.

●      Broader Impacts

○      STEM education: As the above intellectual merit results show, this project has contributed significant improvements to STEM education in the technology field.

○      Societal well-being: The point of universal design is to design technology that provides productivity and other benefits to more people in society.  That is the skill students gained, and when they graduate and use those skills, many people who use technology will benefit from the  increased usability these emerging software practitioners can build into technology.

○      STEM workforce: The students graduating under this new approach are demonstrating new types of skills, which in expands the skillset present in the STEM workforce.  They are also staying in the major longer, which increases the quantity of the STEM workforce.

○      Infrastructure: Enhancing infrastructure for research and education. The project produced more than 63 reusable artifacts for other faculty and universities to use, so they too can use the approach.  All of these resources are openly available in the OERcommons site for open education artifacts.
